intro: Dryandra drummondii subsp. macrorufa, commonly known as the Geraldton waxplant, is a flowering plant native to Western Australia. It is characterized by its distinctive, waxy, pink to red flowers that bloom in late winter to early spring. The plant has narrow, needle-like leaves and is adapted to grow in sandy or gravelly soils. It is part of the family Proteaceae and is known for its ornamental value in gardens. This subspecies is often found in coastal and inland regions of Western Australia.
